name: Hellenistic Judaism
description: Hellenistic Judaism represents the fusion of Greek culture and Jewish tradition that emerged after Alexander the Great's conquests. This synthesis produced the Septuagint translation, Philo of Alexandria's philosophical works, and Greek-speaking synagogues - creating a cultural bridge that would prove crucial for the spread of early Christianity. Philip the Apostle, bearing a Greek name, exemplifies this cultural bridge.
shortDescription: The synthesis of Greek culture and Jewish tradition that produced the Septuagint, Philo's philosophy, and Greek-speaking synagogues - the cultural matrix from which Philip's evangelism emerged.

septuagint.name: Septuagint (LXX)

greeksSeekingJesus.text: Now there were some Greeks among those who went up to worship at the festival. They came to Philip, who was from Bethsaida in Galilee, with a request. 'Sir,' they said, 'we would like to see Jesus.'
philipRole: Philip (Greek name) approached by Greeks seeking Jesus
Philip went to Andrew (also Greek name) before approaching Jesus
Both were from Bethsaida - Galilean town with Greek influence
significance: Greeks approaching Philip reflects his Hellenistic cultural context
Foreshadows Gentile mission of the Church
Philip as bridge between Jewish and Greek worlds
Jesus' response speaks of his 'hour' having come - universal salvation
greeksSeekingJesus.jesusResponse: The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified. Unless a grain of wheat falls into the ground and dies, it remains alone; but if it dies, it produces much grain.
